conclusion: A plank of length L = 0.60 m and mass M = 0.40 kg is leaning against a smooth vertical wall. A block of mass m = 0.80 kg is at the lower right end of the plank. Force F₁ is applied horizontally to the left on the block, and force F₂ is applied vertically upward on the plank. The coefficient of friction μ = 0.20 between the block and plank. Gravity g = 10 m/s².

The plank is leaning against a smooth vertical wall, and a block is at the lower right end of the plank. Force F₁ is applied horizontally to the left on the block, and force F₂ is applied vertically upward on the plank.
There is no resistance to the plank's upward motion along the wall.
Coordinate system is set with x-axis horizontal (positive to the right) and y-axis vertical (positive upward).

premise: Forces on the block: Weight mg downward, Force F₁ to the left, Normal force N from the plank perpendicular to the plank, Frictional force f parallel to the plank.
conclusion: The normal force must be perpendicular to the plank for the block to move up the plank.

premise: The normal force acts at angle θ from the vertical.
conclusion: The components of the normal force are N·sin(θ) in the x-direction and N·cos(θ) in the y-direction.

premise: For the block to remain on the plank, the normal force must balance forces perpendicular to the plank.
The maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction: f = μN.
For the plank to move upward, the upward force must overcome the combined weight of the plank and block, plus any downward component of F₁.
Substituting for f: F₂ + μ(mg·cos(θ) + F₁·sin(θ))·sin(θ) − Mg − mg + F₁·cos(θ) > 0
conclusion: F₂ + μ(mg·cos(θ) + F₁·sin(θ))·sin(θ) − Mg − mg + F₁·cos(θ) > 0

premise: The plank has length L = 0.60 m and is leaning against the wall.
